Rosaleen.Action: Remains asleep and unresponsive despite family members urging her to come downstairs and interact, causing frustration.
Remains asleep and unresponsive to repeated calls from Alice and family despite their attempts to engage her.
Turns over in bed smiling, showing a calm, self-possessed demeanor.
Looks uncertainly at Mother and down miserably at sister's coffin, indicating emotional uncertainty and lack of confidence.
Eagerly asks Granny to tell her the story despite being warned she may be too young to understand.
Bites hungrily into the apple given by Granny without showing hesitation or suspicion.
Listens attentively and asks clarifying questions about the wolf's nature and its disguises.
Shows no immediate skepticism about Granny's warning about wolves, trusts Granny's advice implicitly.
Kisses the old woman dutifully when asked, showing polite and respectful behavior.
Glances at Granny uneasily during the night but settles down again without causing trouble or panic.
Walks along the path with Granny, appearing unaware of ominous signs like the snake and howling ermine.
Gently reaches out to touch a large spider despite possible fear or disgust, showing curiosity and calmness.
Takes the bouquet from her father assertively and defends her choice to walk with the neighbor’s son, indicating confidence and standing up for herself.
Does not back down from her position despite parental teasing and concern, showing resolve and self-assurance.
Looks around, smiles, and climbs a tree happily to reach the bird’s nest, showing joy and curiosity.
Takes a hand mirror from the nest and applies rouge to her lips while observing herself.
Takes one of the tiny homunculi from the cracked eggs in the nest and contemplates it quietly.
Calmly approaches and reaches out to touch a severed hand that others reacted to with fear and aversion.
Asks pointed questions about the severed hand's identity and nature, showing curiosity and seeking understanding.
Does not show fear or panic in the presence of a frightening and gruesome object, demonstrating emotional composure.
Cautiously approaches the well and slowly lowers herself down into it, showing careful and deliberate movement.
Petting the docile wolf calmly, indicating she can handle potentially dangerous situations with composure.
States 'And that's all I'll tell you, because that's all I know,' showing honesty but also an acknowledgement of limited knowledge or agency.
Wearing makeup such as bright red lipstick and rouge, showing awareness of appearance.
Lies fully dressed atop her bed asleep despite disturbance around her, indicating passivity or disengagement.
Tossing in her sleep but not reacting consciously to surrounding events such as blowing wind and papers, showing lack of active response or control.
Tosses uneasily in her sleep, showing restlessness or anxiety but no direct action or control.
Turns over on the bed, smiling.
Stares down silently at the churchyard during funeral.
Kisses her deceased sister's forehead uncertainly and miserably.
Stoops down to kiss Alice's forehead despite feeling uncertain and miserable
Interacts playfully with red-haired boy by sticking out her tongue, shows a moment of lighthearted connection
Turns her head away after the boy's mother scolds him, showing sensitivity and respect for social boundaries
Clings to Father and calls him 'Daddy' seeking comfort.
Pulls free from Granny's arm and insists on staying with her mother despite others' concerns.
Darts away excitedly upon seeing berries in the woods.
Picks a berry and pops it into her mouth, showing innocence and trust in Granny's guidance.
Asks Granny for an apple politely, showing friendliness and trust.
Runs ahead happily toward Granny's cottage, indicating a sense of comfort and openness.
Eagerly listens to Granny's stories and engages in conversation, showing interest and respect.
Bites hungrily into the apple given by Granny, showing trust and acceptance.
Follows Granny into the cottage without hesitation, indicating trust and close relationship.
She smiles uncertainly, gets into bed and snuggles down against the pillow to wait for him.
Freezes in terror when a wolf howls outside, then forces herself towards the window.
Expresses firm refusal to tolerate a man striking her.
Listens attentively to Granny's story and questions about wolves and dogs.
Looks away instead of giving Granny a kiss after the story.
Kisses the old woman (Granny) on the cheek dutifully.
Glances uneasily at Granny but settles down beside her.
Plays a friendly game with the village boy, inviting him to play a playful water game.
Startled by doves flying out of the well but continues with daily chores calmly.
No negative or unfriendly behavior observed; generally interacts in a good-natured, innocent manner.
Asks her mother tenderly if Daddy hurts her, showing concern.
Politely declines the boy's invitation to a walk, with a cautious but not rude tone.
Engages quietly with Granny beside the tombstones, showing some family connection but no explicit warmth shown.
Smiles to herself as the boy takes the jar from the Prince of Darkness
Sits up in bed and looks at the boy screaming in the mirror, showing concern.
Interrupts the storytelling with a candid comment 'That's a horrid story! I didn't like it at all.'
Whispers a skeptical and somewhat irreverent remark about the priest 'The Devil's one thing, but a priest making babies is another!'
Tries on the red shawl with delight, interacting positively with Granny.
Laughs at Granny's mischievous remark about the priest attempting to hit her, showing a playful, friendly connection.
Sits up in bed and turns to look at the boy screaming in the mirror, indicating awareness and attentiveness.
Expresses clear dislike of a story and voices skepticism about the priest's ability to be immoral, showing critical thinking and confidence.
Tries on the shawl delightedly and comments on its softness and color, demonstrating engagement and some decisiveness.
Whispers about the priest making babies, showing a private, possibly naive or speculative comment without further exploration.
Gently tries to touch the spider, showing a kind curiosity rather than fear or violence.
Defends her interest in walking with the neighbour's son against her parents' teasing and concern.
Looks up at the boy and grins crookedly during church service.
Calmly brushes away spiders that fall onto her prayer book without showing fear or disgust.
Calmly brushes away spiders falling onto her prayer book instead of reacting with fear or panic.
Grins crookedly at the boy, demonstrating social awareness and confidence.
Glances up at the ceiling and looks down at spiders, showing observation but not overt engagement or interference beyond brushing them away.
Pushes the boy away when he kisses her, denies liking him initially.
Admits to liking the boy 'well enough' and eventually kisses him.
Playfully challenges the boy to catch her after pushing him away.
Runs away multiple times, avoiding close contact and emotional engagement.
Runs away from the boy, seemingly escaping danger or a difficult situation.
Appears quietly and calmly shows her mother the tiny homunculi in her hand, conveying information without panic.
Helps father into his cloak, demonstrating attentiveness and supportive behavior.
Remains largely silent and non-confrontational amidst the chaos of the fight and accusations.
Speaks scornfully about village boys, calling them clowns.
Shares thoughtful, tolerant idea that wolves may not be as terrible as believed.
Skillfully begins to tell a story with intrigue and a smile, engaging the listener.
Provides vague, hesitant answers ('Maybe I am'), showing some reluctance or hesitation.

Walks calmly and with hostile curiosity into a tense situation, confronts the groom and bride openly, uses sharp symbolic acts (biting and spitting out the apple, standing before the mirror) to assert herself.
Provokes strong reactions (shock, gasps) from others, but maintains composure and control, indicating confidence and purposeful behavior.
Smiles coldly and laughs harshly after causing disturbance, showing emotional control mixed with a biting wit, displaying psychological insight and strength.
Clearly communicates a story she believes to be true with confidence and conviction when speaking to her mother.
Unable to persuade or fully convince her mother, who reacts with skepticism and laughter, indicating a possible lack of effective persuasion skills.
Asks calmly and sincerely about the severed hand, showing curiosity and lack of fear.
Moves calmly to touch the severed hand despite others' distress, showing bravery but also disregard for others' discomfort.
Asks thoughtfully whether to bury or burn the hand, showing concern about what to do with something disturbing.
Cries in her sleep, showing vulnerability and emotional openness.
Bends down to feed the geese with grain, showing care for animals.
Confidently asserts that she'll be safe in the forest now, possibly indicating some naivety or overconfidence rather than warmth.
Insists on staying the night with her grandmother out of respect and concern for her loneliness.
Responds scornfully to the Boy's offer to accompany her through the woods, referencing a past negative experience.
Smiles and confidently shows she can protect herself, asserting independence.
Looks up in alarm, reaches for her knife, backs away warily from the Huntsman.
Engages in cautious but polite conversation with the Huntsman.
Refuses to share her drink intended for her Granny.
Accepts cake from the Huntsman and shares a tentative bite.
Questions the huntsman's claims and expresses skepticism about his compass and the existence of werewolves.
Laughs when the huntsman kisses her after seizing her and rolling her on the ground.
Questioning the Huntsman's claims and expressing skepticism about the compass despite seeing it.
Warning the Huntsman about never leaving the path and being afraid of wolves, showing awareness of dangers.
Dismissing village boys as clowns, showing confidence and a critical mind.
Laughing off the Huntsman's forceful kiss and bet challenge without apparent objection or concern.
Engages in playful bet and accepts Huntsman's token of goodwill, smiling at herself in the mirror wearing his hat.
Approaches the cottage despite the ominous atmosphere and visible danger signals (blood on the snow, wolves howling)
Responds calmly and reassuringly to the Huntsman’s falsetto voice at the door ('Only your granddaughter')
Moves hurriedly towards the cottage after noticing the blood on the snow
Expresses concern for Granny's safety, criticizes the huntsman for letting an old lady go out alone on a dangerous night.
Grows defensive and confrontational toward the huntsman when she suspects harm to Granny, brandishes a knife to protect herself.
Destroys Granny's glasses accidentally but shows recognition of their symbolic loss by staring at the fire burning Granny's hair.
Recalls Granny's teachings and stands firm against the huntsman despite fear, demonstrating loyalty and trust in Granny's wisdom.
Removes and throws the shawl into the fire at the huntsman's prompting, acknowledging the symbolic finality, showing acceptance rather than panic.
Expresses sympathy for the wolves, calling them 'poor creatures' and showing understanding for their howling in the cold.
Seizes the Huntsman's rifle and shoots it to stop him, acting boldly and showing protective instincts toward herself and/or others.
Questions the Huntsman about his nature and his place between worlds, showing curiosity and engagement without hostility.
Comments on the Huntsman's arms in a playful, slightly flirtatious way, showing friendliness and openness.
Acknowledges the Huntsman's win of his bet and reminds him about the owed kiss, displaying sincerity and good-natured acceptance.
Says the she-wolf meant no harm and someone meant harm to her, showing sympathy.
Narrates the wolf's vulnerable and painful attempts to seek refuge, highlighting compassion for her plight.
Speaks with understanding and empathy about the she-wolf's intentions and suffering ('She meant no harm... but someone meant harm to her.')
Only provides voiceover commentary; does not intervene or change the course of events despite apparent knowledge
Presents a voiceover showing empathy and sorrow for the Wolf Girl's pain and journey, reflects on her vulnerability and memories.
Pets the docile wolf gently at the hearth, indicating a caring and tender demeanor.
Clutches the covers and screams in terror as the wolf bursts into her room.
Lies asleep unaware of the approaching wolves.
Screams in terror when threatened by the wolf coming through the window.
Internal voice delivers a cautious and wise warning to 'never trust a stranger friend' and 'wolves may lurk in every guise'.
